factoid: Tears suddenly rose in the woman's eyes.
The woman turned away.
The woman lifted her music before her eyes.
The woman began singing again.
The woman again began walking up and down the room.
Pétya came running in from the drawing room.
Pétya was a handsome rosy lad of fifteen.
Pétya had full red lips.
Pétya resembled Natásha.
Pétya was preparing to enter the university.
Pétya and his friend Obolénski had, in secret, agreed to join the hussars.
Pétya had come rushing out to talk to his namesake about this affair.
Pétya had asked Pierre to find out whether Pétya would be accepted in the hussars.
Pierre walked up and down the drawing room.
Pierre was not listening to what Pétya was saying.
Pétya pulled Pierre by the arm to attract Pierre's attention.
Pétya said, "Well, what about my plan?"
Pétya said, "Peter Kirílych, for heaven’s sake!"
Pétya said, "You are my only hope."
Pierre said, "Oh yes, your plan."
Pierre said, "To join the hussars?"
Pierre said, "I’ll mention it."
Pierre said, "I’ll bring it all up today."
The old count asked, "Well, mon cher, have you got the manifesto?"
The countess has been to Mass at the Razumóvskis’ and heard the new prayer.
The countess says that it is very fine.
Pierre said, "Yes, I’ve got it."
Pierre said, "The Emperor is to be here tomorrow."
Pierre said, "There’s an Extraordinary Meeting of the nobility tomorrow."
Pierre said, "They are talking of a levy of ten men per thousand."
Pierre said, "Oh yes, let me congratulate you!"
Pierre replied, "Yes, yes, thank God!"
Pierre replied, "Well, and what news from the army?"
Pierre replied, "We are again retreating."
Pierre replied, "They say we’re already near Smolénsk."
The count exclaimed, "O Lord, O Lord!"
The count said, "Where is the manifesto?"
Pierre began feeling in his pockets for the papers.
Pierre could not find the papers.
Pierre slapped his pockets.
Pierre kissed the hand of the countess.
The countess entered the room.
The countess glanced uneasily around.
The countess was evidently expecting Natásha.
Natásha had left off singing.
Natásha had not yet come into the drawing room.
The old count said, "On my word, I don’t know what I’ve done with it."
The countess remarked, "There he is, always losing everything!"
Natásha entered with a softened and agitated expression of face.
Natásha sat down looking silently at Pierre.
Pierre’s features, which had been gloomy, suddenly lighted up.
Pierre glanced at Natásha several times.
Pierre said, "No, really!"
Pierre said, "I’ll drive home."
Pierre said, "I must have left them there."
Pierre said, "I’ll certainly…"
Pierre said, "But you’ll be late for dinner."
Pierre said, "Oh! And my coachman has gone."
Sónya had gone to look for the papers in the anteroom.
Sónya had found the papers in Pierre’s hat.
Pierre had carefully tucked the papers under the lining.
Pierre was about to begin reading.
The old count said, "No, after dinner."
The old count was evidently expecting much enjoyment from that reading.
At dinner, champagne was drunk to the health of the new chevalier of St. George.
Shinshín told them the town news.
The town news included the illness of the old Georgian princess.
The town news included Métivier’s disappearance from Moscow.
The town news included that some German fellow had been brought to Rostopchín and accused of being a French "spyer".
Count Rostopchín had told the story.
Rostopchín let the German fellow go.
Rostopchín assured the people that the German fellow was "not a spire at all, but only an old German ruin."
The count said, "People are being arrested..."
The count said, "I’ve told the countess she should not speak French so much."
The count said, "It’s not the time for it now."
Shinshín asked, "And have you heard?"
Shinshín said, "Prince Golítsyn has engaged a master to teach him Russian."
Shinshín said, "It is becoming dangerous to speak French in the streets."
The old count remarked, "And how about you, Count Peter Kirílych?"
The old count remarked, "If they call up the militia, you too will have to mount a horse."
The old count addressed Pierre.
Pierre had been silent and preoccupied all through dinner.
Pierre did not seem to grasp what was said.
Pierre looked at the count.
Pierre said, "Oh yes, the war."
Pierre said, "No! What sort of warrior should I make?"
Pierre said, "And yet everything is so strange, so strange!"
Pierre said, "I can’t make it out."
Pierre said, "I don’t know."
Pierre said, "I am very far from having military tastes."
Pierre said, "In these times no one can answer for himself."
